title: RP tests
text: chapter 7 Hastie, Tibshirani, Friedman (2009) authors emphasize cross-validation estimates expected prediction error (generalization error) method. contrast estimating errors specific model. line work makes use cross-validation inherits inferential focus method rather specific model chosen method (Wasserman Roeder 2009; Meinshausen, Meier, Bühlmann 2009; Meinshausen Bühlmann 2010; R. D. Shah Samworth 2013) including focus vignette proposed R. D. Shah Bühlmann (2018). paper R implementation (2021) roughly attempt answer question: method (typically) result models good fit, fail capture signal alternate method (typically) detect? first method fit well, residuals method (typically) look like pure noise. hand, alternate method can predict residuals good accuracy (better noise) evidence first method failing capture signal. Hence name RPtests, based residual prediction. exact details depend several (groups ) decisions: Probability modeling assumptions (foundational, question ).\[ \mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \beta + \sigma \epsilon \] first method, null method. want know method good enough. focus using lasso (1996) select variables (potentially high-dimensional) linear model. (high level idea applied using methods well require changing details implementation). One secondary alternate methods chosen depending type model misspecification concerned . focus whether include predictor variables, another possibility search non-linear relationships. (alternate method hybrid ensemble several methods, explore ). Analysis/pipeline choices including tune method, estimating variance noise, number bootstrap samples, . (also question ). ’ll focus one main cases investigated (R. D. Shah Bühlmann 2018): testing linear model alternative includes additional predictors. determine alternative predicts residuals significantly better noise paper uses parametric-residual bootstrap described , first consider important point dimension first (null) model.

title: RP tests
text: low dimensional linear model case, scaled residuals \[ \hat{\mathbf{R}} = \frac{(\mathbf{} - \mathbf{P})\mathbf{y}}{\|(\mathbf{} - \mathbf{P})\mathbf{y}\|_2} \] pivotal quantity null hypothesis model fits (\(\mathbf P = \mathbf{X}(\mathbf{X}^T \mathbf{X})^{-1} \mathbf{X}^T\) projection hat matrix). case distribution residuals depend unknown parameters, can use distribution valid hypothesis tests inferences. basis standard \(F\)-test goodness--fit, one reported end summary(lm(y ~ x)). However, work high-dimensional case, (2018) use combination previous lasso theory new technical results prove residuals lasso can used similar way (slight modifications) construct tests. theory relies fairly standard strong conditions sufficient lasso estimate support signs true \(\beta\) high probability, (typical lasso theory literature) simulations show good empirical performance general settings strong sufficient conditions relaxed. briefly note Janková et al. (2020) apply basic idea predicting residuals high-dimensional generalized linear models using Pearson residuals \[ \hat R_i = \frac{Y_i - \mu(x_i^T \hat \beta)}{\sqrt{V(x_i^T \hat \beta)}} \] instead, \(\mu\) \(V\) conditional mean variance functions, respectively. However, beyond basic idea much additional work involved case consider .
code: set.seed(1) x <- runif(50) y <- x + rnorm(50) summary(lm(y ~ x)) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ x) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -1.9115 -0.5747 -0.1463  0.5103  2.2936  #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   #> (Intercept)  0.06272    0.29121   0.215   0.8304   #> x            1.06779    0.48788   2.189   0.0335 * #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.9297 on 48 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.09074,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.0718  #> F-statistic:  4.79 on 1 and 48 DF,  p-value: 0.03352

title: RP tests
text: calibrate test, need distribution compare accuracy measure (typically) achieved null model. high-dimensional case null model assumed selected lasso cross-validation. authors propose iterating whole procedure multiple times average randomness induced cross-validation . Note makes sense inferential focus method specific model chosen method. restatement Algorithm 1 (2018), parametric-residual bootstrap procedure estimating null distribution. \(b = 1, \ldots, B\): Replace \(\mathbf{y}\) \(\mathbf{\hat y}\) original null model plus simulated residuals \(\mathbf{\zeta}^{(b)} \sim N(0, \mathbf{}_{n \times n})\). (Simulating new response null model). Fit sqrt-lasso (2011) using simulated \(\mathbf{y}^{(b)}\) subtract new fit \(\mathbf{\hat y}^{(b)}\). (Simulating residuals achieved alternative method). Normalize simulated residuals compute accuracy measure, RSS. (Obtain bootstrap distribution testing). Note sqrt-lasso method can replaced fitting procedures interested different alternatives, example using tree based method interested predictive interactions. Exercise: just predict normalized residuals \((\mathbf{y} - \mathbf{\hat y})/\hat \sigma\) compare accuracy predicting \(\mathbf{\zeta}^{(b)}\)? (Consider dimensions).

title: RP tests
text: continue focusing high-dimensional linear model alternative selected model consider whether variables included. Since (2018) trying selective inference simulations seems model selection involved choosing hypotheses. Type 1 error control shown simulations set null true instances, rather model selection subsetting instances null holds (selective inference). Iterate
code: library(RPtests) library(hdi) # riboflavin dataset #> Loading required package: scalreg #> Loading required package: lars #> Loaded lars 1.3 library(purrr) library(tidyverse) #> ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.1 ── #> ✔ ggplot2 3.3.6     ✔ dplyr   1.0.9 #> ✔ tibble  3.1.8     ✔ stringr 1.4.1 #> ✔ tidyr   1.2.0     ✔ forcats 0.5.1 #> ✔ readr   2.1.2 #> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── #> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() #> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag() devtools::load_all() # this shouldn't be necessary? #> ℹ Loading unbiasedgoodness library(unbiasedgoodness) set.seed(1) n <- 100 p <- 200 s0 <- 5 sim_data <- rXb(n, p, s0, xtype = "equi.corr") x <- sim_data$x beta <- sim_data$beta y <- x %*% beta + rnorm(n) # True support which(beta != 0) #> [1] 1 2 3 4 5 gof_RPtest(x, y) #> Warning in gof_RPtest(x, y): Sparsity of 1 chosen by cv.glmnet, forcing to 2 for RPtest compatibility #> $selected_support #> [1]   5 139 #>  #> $alt_support #> [1]   3   4  85 133 166 190 #>  #> $pval_lasso #> [1] 0.02 #>  #> $pval_OLS #> [1] 0.02 #>  #> $pval_full #> [1] 0.02 #devtools::load_all() # this shouldn't be necessary? library(unbiasedgoodness) set.seed(1) n <- 100 p <- 200 s0 <- 5 m <- 1.2 b <- 5  simulate_gof_instance(m, b = 10, n, p, s0) #>    max_corr   min_beta s_null s_alt null_intersection alt_intersection  null #> 1 0.5636253 0.03821633      4     6                 4                4 FALSE #>     alt pval_lasso pval_OLS pval_full #> 1 FALSE       0.04     0.04      0.52 #devtools::load_all() # this shouldn't be necessary? library(unbiasedgoodness) set.seed(1) niters <- 500 output <- simulate_gof(niters, m, b = 10, n, p, s0) #> Warning in gof_RPtest(x, y): Sparsity of 1 chosen by cv.glmnet, forcing to 2 for RPtest compatibility  #> Warning in gof_RPtest(x, y): Sparsity of 1 chosen by cv.glmnet, forcing to 2 for RPtest compatibility output |>    summarize(null = mean(null),             alt = mean(alt),             s_null = mean(s_null),             s_alt = mean(s_alt)) #>    null   alt s_null s_alt #> 1 0.452 0.548  8.756 7.774 output |>   ggplot(aes(pval_OLS)) +   geom_histogram() +   facet_grid(~null) #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. output |>   ggplot(aes(pval_full)) +   geom_histogram() +   facet_grid(~null) #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. output |>   ggplot(aes(pval_lasso)) +   geom_histogram() +   facet_grid(~null) #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: RP tests
code: library(tidyverse) output %>% pull(null_intersection) %>% qplot() #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. output %>% pull(alt_intersection) %>% qplot() #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. output |> pull(s_alt) |> qplot() #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. output |> ggplot(aes(max_corr, null_intersection)) +    geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x' output |> ggplot(aes(min_beta, null_intersection)) +    geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x' output %>% pull(null_intersection) |> qplot() #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

code: n <- 100 p <- 200 s0 <- 5 sim_data <- rXb(n, p, s0) #> Error in rXb(n, p, s0): could not find function "rXb" x <- sim_data$x #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'sim_data' not found beta <- sim_data$beta #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'sim_data' not found y <- x %*% beta + rnorm(n) #> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'x' not found gof_RPtest(x, y) #> Error in nrow(x): object 'x' not found
